name: Voice Reservation Bot
one_liner: AI answers phones for small businesses — books appointments and takes reservations

brief.problem: Small businesses (restaurants, salons, clinics) miss calls and lose customers because they can not afford receptionists.
brief.target_user: Restaurants, salons, clinics, and trades that rely on phone bookings
brief.proposed_solution: AI voice agent that answers calls, books appointments, takes reservations, and answers FAQs. Integrates with existing calendar/booking systems.
brief.value_prop: Never miss a call again — AI receptionist for $50/month instead of $3,000/month for a human
brief.initial_revenue_model: Monthly subscription per business ($30-100/mo) + usage-based pricing for high volume

ai_leverage.reasoning: Voice AI is the entire product. Leverages latest speech-to-text and LLM tech for natural conversations.

competition.reasoning: Growing space with well-funded competitors. Bland AI, Slang, others raising money. Medium-high competition.

bootstrappability.reasoning: Requires voice AI infrastructure, telephony integration, calendar APIs. Significant upfront build.

revenue_clarity.reasoning: Clear SaaS model with strong unit economics. $50-100/mo per business is proven price point in this space.

passive_potential.reasoning: Requires active sales, onboarding, and support. Not passive at all.

team_fit.reasoning: Ben has some voice AI consulting experience but team lacks sales/BD muscle needed for SMB.

side_project_viability.reasoning: Hard to run as a side project — needs dedicated sales and customer support.

market_timing.reasoning: Voice AI just became good enough. Perfect timing — early enough to build but tech is mature.

summary: Voice Reservation Bot has strong revenue potential and perfect market timing, but requires significant build effort and active sales that do not fit a side project model. Competition is growing fast with well-funded players. Best suited for a team that can go full-time. Could revisit if team dynamics change.
